posts.name: Noah LazerBeams
posts.cooked:
I’ve been trying to get MAXMotion position control working for a while now. Everything else works. MAXMotion velocity control? Beautiful. Regular closed loop position? Amazing. But for some reason whenever i set a reference to a goal using ControlType.kMAXMotionPositionControl, it doesn’t do anything. it just stares. Menacingly. I’d really like to understand why. I tried resetting the SparkMax. No dice.

This is the code I’ve been running MAXMotionTest/src/main/java/frc/robot at main · NoahLacks/MAXMotionTest

I also tried using REV’s example. Somehow it made thing’s worse. MAXMotion velocity control now just stutters in place. And MAXMotion position control still does nothing. REVLib-Examples/Java/SPARK/MAXMotion/src/main/java/frc/robot/Robot.java at main · REVrobotics/REVLib-Examples

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Correct; MaxPosition is not exactly a good, usable tool due to the inability to pull in feed-forwards (which is what enables robust tracking for a motion profile).

You can search CD for the reasons why, but common wisdom is to just avoid it and use the ProfilePID class entirely, or use a TrapezoidalProfile and feed the PID target to the rev PID .

As a rev team ourselves, it’s unfortunate. Having this work reliably would be awesome.

posts.name: Noah LazerBeams
posts.cooked:
Wow really? So that’s very unfortunate. I’ve spent a lot of time on this. That’s kinda ridiculous that they’d release something that doesn’t really work. But perhaps I’m just salty.

As for what you’re suggesting. You’re saying to calculate the individual setpoints on the rio using TrapazoidalProfile, then feeding it into the on controller pid. Alternatively, closed loop controllers are best to be avoided

posts.name: Carter Ryba
posts.cooked:
We have it working on our robot, it’s reliable but it’s not very intuitive to implement. And we had to add an I term to stop it from oscillating. Wish you could add feed forward.

Figure out how to do it the way @tekdemo said, unless you absolutely need it working now.

Our code: REEFSCAPE/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/elevator/ElevatorSubsystem.java at main · Team10219/REEFSCAPE · GitHub

Frankly, we need to implement a better way aswell.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
It’s not that it doesn’t work in theory (it does) it’s just that several of the implementation details it doesn’t handle are important, and can get in the way of making it work well.

I’ll be honest though: I got so burned on SmartMotion’s even worse implementation I haven’t played with MaxMotion much; This new version at least fixes several issues, but still doesn’t have optimal ways to handle feedforward for good tracking (notably kv and ka). It’s relying on feedback to operate properly, which  is why it sometimes gets in quirky instability loops, and needs I and D terms to be stable.

As for the process, the WPILib profile tools don’t generate a “trajectory” full of specific points and times (eg, how PathPlanner+choreo works), but rather just re-calculate the next motion every loop that’s within the constraints. This allows it to properly compensate for disturbances or errors. Unlike drivetrains, a simple trapezoidal, single actuator model is very simple and can be done in real time even on the Rio.

We have this stripped down to a pretty streamlined command, using Wpilib feed-forwards and profile, and onboard rev PID . We used this with great success this season. Should help you get started if you need.

https://github.com/stormbots/Reefscape/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/Elevator/Elevator.java#L235

This does have one bug though: We need to duplicate the armgoal=... line from the execute block and put it in the start block too. Otherwise, your triggers might compare the current position and last goal, incorrectly triggering a “motion completed” when you first set the motion. This doesn’t affect the actual control loop though, so it runs fine as is, but might surprise you if you use it in a sequence without a debounce on your exit condition triggers.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: You’re not salty. It’s a problem, and just one of reasons why teams like the ctre software stack.

after reading 2910’s thread and seeing they dont use feedforwards with motion magic this year, they’re basically using max motion but on ctre devices, at least to my understanding… is max motion really that bad?

also, the suggestion to use a profiled pid controller: isnt that a trapezoidal profile without feedforwards? running on the rio at slower speeds?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Look at the number of motors 2910 has on each mechanism.  If you add enough power to make the feedforward only a fraction of a volt, it matters a lot less.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
AvocadoPeel:

is max motion really that bad?

Feedforward is one of the easiest ways to get a tracking performance improvement. MAX Motion’s documentation recommending against feedforward makes me think there’s an issue with their implementation, because other vendors ( CTRE , WPILib) haven’t seen the issue REV is warning about.

AvocadoPeel:

isnt that a trapezoidal profile without feedforwards?

Yes, but you can add a feedforward to the output yourself by querying the setpoints. If you want something more specific than what ProfiledPIDController provides, I recommend just doing the plumbing manually:

AvocadoPeel:

running on the rio at slower speeds?

Almost all FRC mechanisms can be well-controlled at 50 Hz or higher. An important factor to consider for system stability is the maximum time between control input updates. Java’s nondeterministic GC pauses can increase this metric to the 100-200 ms range, so teams compensate by running feedback on the motor controller instead.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
NoahLacks:

I hate closed loops and they should feel bad. Just do it all on the rio

I don’t think this is an accurate summary: We all love closed loops, and there’s a reason most teams run them on motor controllers (better, more consistent loop cycles).

Most of us here are just directing you away from footguns and time sinks. MaxMotion kind of just falls into this, even when other similar solutions ( CTRE Motion Magic, Rio profiles) are highly recommended to do the job.

I think it’s more accurate to say MaxMotion is bad because

It may not work well for some mechanisms due to limitations in it’s implementation, wasting time and effort to get it working

If it does work, it probably didn’t save time or effort over doing it on the Rio to begin with

Because of the limitations, having it in place can block performance enhancement paths; Forcing time and effort in getting MaxMotion up and in replacing it.

If it doesn’t save time and effort, and isn’t a valuable learning target, why bother.

posts.name: Kade Dressing
posts.cooked:
I looked into your code, I have a couple possible fixes.

Firstly, I would recommend adding this to your code in ClosedLoopTestConstants.java after line 54:

Secondly, something I did (don’t know how good this really is for the motor and whatever), but I had my maxVelocity and my maxAcceleration REALLY high, but that could be because I calculated my gear ratio incorrectly…

Anyways, your maxVelocity and maxAcceleration are 360 and 180 respectively, but maybe try increasing those, because I had to increase mine a ton to get my robot’s elevator moving.

For example, my maxAcceleration is 7500, and my maxVelocity is 2000000, but after I think like 200000, it stopped changing how fast it’d go for me.

I’d also try adjusting your PID because for whatever reason, because when I swapped from using kPosition to kMaxPosition, I had to increase my P value. I’d also maybe change your .pidf in kMotorConfig.encoder to .pid with only the P, I, and D values.

Cause I had the same issue when I first tried using kMaxPosition, and I had to adjust all those values till it decided it wanted to work.

I think what made it work for me though was the line I told you to add after line 54, because the point of using kMaxPosition is to have acceleration and the acceleration happens because of trapezoidal PID movement.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
You can test your velocity and acceleration set points by graphing acceleration and velocity of your mechanism to see if they are meeting your targets.

If your targets are set higher than the velocity and acceleration plots, you’re asking your mechanism to do something it can’t do, or you have your other constants set incorrectly.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
We used MaxMotion on elevator and arm this year.  The elevator we added arb feedforward after a regional.

Some tips from our experiences:

If it isn’t moving, you may have not set max Accel to velocity high enough.  This can be a units mismatch possibly.

You can graph output voltage to see how much is being applied.  We messed up converting from rpm and rpm/s a couple times at least, which is multiplied by the conversion factor.

We used a relative throughbore encoder for the elevator and a absolute throughbore for arm. Which matching all the units in the new configs for them was new to us.

The kP was not too sensitive so it seemed to work okay in a large range for us.

The kP was not too sensitive so it seemed to work okay in a large range for us.

We dealt with endpoint jitter by adding some error tolerance, which worked fine for us.  We settled on 4 mm for elevator tolerance.

We dealt with endpoint jitter by adding some error tolerance, which worked fine for us.  We settled on 4 mm for elevator tolerance.
